event.title: taken from the Creel Burial Mound in South Charleston now

data.event: -- Photographs of artifacts taken from the Creel Burial Mound in South Charleston now have a permanent home at the new Mound Interpretive Center next to the LaBelle Theater in South Charleston.

event.title: designed the original trail from Virginia Beach, Va., to Cedar Grove in 1790

data.event: In fact, Hypes said George Washington designed the original trail from Virginia Beach, Va., to Cedar Grove in 1790.

The largest remaining one is the South Charleston Mound, which is estimated to have been built between 250 and 100 B.C. "This is the first time in 125 years that people can see what artifacts were discovered in the mound," said Mayor Mullins.
Mullins also said he wants school groups to be a part of the center's programs by visiting and taking part in activities planned for the future.
The period of the Adena's existence is estimated from 500 BC to 1000 AD.
When the center opens Friday, there will be a group of school children from South Charleston among the first visitors.
"It's the community's place now and we hope folks will visit often."
